Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 1, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
More than 3,000 years ago, 
a flower began to appear in remedies in Ancient Egyptian medical texts. Across the Mediterranean, 
the ancient Minoans likely found ways to use 
the same plant for its high. Both ancient civilizations 
were on to something— opium, 
an extract of the poppy in question, can both induce pleasure 
and reduce pain. Though opium has remained 
in use ever since, it wasn’t until the 19th century 
that one of its chemical compounds, morphine, was identified 
and isolated for medical use. Morphine, codeine, and other substances 
made directly from the poppy are called opiates. In the 20th century, drug companies 
created a slew of synthetic substances similar to these opiates, including heroin, hydrocodone, 
oxycodone, and fentanyl. Whether synthetic or derived from opium, these compounds 
are collectively known as opioids. Synthetic or natural, legal or illicit, 
opioid drugs are very effective painkillers,
but they are also highly addictive. In the 1980s and 90s, pharmaceutical companies began 
to market opioid painkillers aggressively, actively downplaying 
their addictive potential to both the medical community 
and the public. The number of opioid painkillers 
prescriptions skyrocketed, and so did cases of opioid addiction, 
beginning a crisis that continues today. To understand why opioids 
are so addictive, it helps to trace how these drugs affect 
the human body from the first dose, through repeated use, 
to what happens when long-term use stops. Each of these drugs 
has slightly different chemistry, but all act on the body’s opioid system by
binding to opioid receptors in the brain. The body’s endorphins temper pain signals 
by binding to these receptors, and opioid drugs bind 
much more strongly, for longer. So opioid drugs can manage much more 
severe pain than endorphins can. Opioid receptors also influence everything
from mood to normal bodily functions. With these functions, too, 
opioids’ binding strength and durability mean their effects 
are more pronounced and widespread than those of the body’s 
natural signaling molecules. When a drug binds to opioid receptors, 
it triggers the release of dopamine, which is linked to feelings of pleasure 
and may be responsible for the sense of euphoria 
that characterizes an opioid high. At the same time, opioids suppress 
the release of noradrenaline, which influences wakefulness, breathing, 
digestion, and blood pressure. A therapeutic dose decreases noradrenaline
enough to cause side effects like constipation. At higher doses opioids can decrease heart
and breathing rates to dangerous levels, causing loss of consciousness 
and even death. Over time, the body starts 
to develop a tolerance for opioids. It may decrease its number 
of opioid receptors, or the receptors may become 
less responsive. To experience the same release of dopamine
and resulting mood effects as before, people have to take 
larger and larger doses— a cycle that leads to physical dependence 
and addiction. As people take more opioids 
to compensate for tolerance, noradrenaline levels 
become lower and lower, to a point that could impact 
basic bodily functions. The body compensates by increasing 
its number of noradrenaline receptors so it can detect much smaller amounts 
of noradrenaline. This increased sensitivity 
to noradrenaline allows the body 
to continue functioning normally— in fact, it becomes dependent on opioids 
to maintain the new balance. When someone who is physically dependent 
on opioids stops taking them abruptly, that balance is disrupted. Noradrenaline levels can increase 
within a day of ceasing opioid use. But the body takes much longer 
to get rid of all the extra noradrenaline receptors 
it made. That means there’s a period of time when the body is too sensitive 
to noradrenaline. This oversensitivity causes 
withdrawal symptoms, including muscle aches, stomach pains, 
fever, and vomiting. Though temporary, opioid withdrawal 
can be incredibly debilitating. In serious cases, someone in withdrawal 
can be violently ill for days or even weeks. People who are addicted to opioids 
aren't necessarily using the drugs to get high anymore, 
but rather to avoid being sick. Many risk losing wages or even jobs 
while in withdrawal, or may not have anyone to take care 
of them during withdrawal. If someone goes back 
to using opioids later, they can be at particularly high risk 
for overdose, because what would have been a standard 
dose while their tolerance was high, can now be lethal. Since 1980, accidental deaths 
from opioid overdose have grown exponentially 
in the United States, and opioid addictions have 
also exploded around the world. While opioid painkiller prescriptions 
are becoming more closely regulated, cases of overdose and addiction 
are still increasing, especially among younger people. Many of the early cases of addiction 
were middle-aged people who became addicted to painkillers 
they had been prescribed, or received from friends 
and family members with prescriptions. Today, young people are often introduced 
to prescription opioid drugs in those ways but move on to heroin or illicit 
synthetic opioids that are cheaper and easier to come by. Beyond tighter regulation 
of opioid painkillers, what can we do to reverse the growing 
rates of addiction and overdose? A drug called naloxone is currently 
our best defense against overdose. Naloxone binds to opioid receptors 
but doesn’t activate them. It blocks other opioids 
from binding to the receptors, and even knocks them off the receptors 
to reverse an overdose. Opioid addiction 
is rarely a stand-alone illness; frequently, people with opioid dependence 
are also struggling with a mental health condition. There are both inpatient 
and outpatient programs that combine medication, health services, 
and psychotherapy. But many of these programs 
are very expensive, and the more affordable options 
can have long waiting lists. They also often require complete 
detoxification from opioids before beginning treatment. Both the withdrawal period and the common 
months-long stay in a facility can be impossible for people who risk 
losing jobs and housing in that timeframe. Opioid maintenance programs aim 
to address some of these obstacles and eliminate opioid abuse 
using a combination of medication and behavior therapy. These programs avoid withdrawal symptoms 
with drugs that bind to opioid receptors 
but don’t have the psychoactive effects of painkillers, heroin, 
and other commonly abused opioids. Methadone and buprenorphine are the primary opioid maintenance 
drugs available today, but doctors need a special waiver 
to prescribe them— even though no specific training 
or certification is required to prescribe 
opioid painkillers. Buprenorphine can be so scarce that there’s even 
a growing black market for it. There’s still a long way to go 
with combating opioid addiction, but there are great resources 
for making sense of the treatment options. If you or someone you know is struggling 
with opioid use in the United States, the Department of Health 
and Human Services operates a helpline: 800-662-4357 and a database of more than 14,000 
substance abuse facilities in the US: www.hhs.gov/opioids

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: What effect does opioid binding have on other neurotransmitters? (select all that apply)*
Options: A. It inhibits the release of dopamine., B. It inhibits the release of noradrenaline., C. It increases the release of dopamine., D. It increases the release of noradrenaline.
Correct Option: B

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What was the first recorded use of opium in medical remedies? Options: A. Ancient Egyptian medical texts, B. Ancient Greek medical texts, C. Ancient Minoan medical texts, D. Ancient Chinese medical texts Correct Option: A
Question 2: How do opioid drugs primarily affect the body's opioid system? Options: A. By blocking opioid receptors, B. By increasing the production of endorphins, C. By decreasing the production of endorphins, D. By binding to opioid receptors Correct Option: D
Question 3: What is the primary cause of withdrawal symptoms in a person who is physically dependent on opioids? Options: A. The sudden decrease in dopamine levels, B. The sudden increase in dopamine levels, C. The sudden decrease in noradrenaline levels, D. The sudden increase in opioid receptors Correct Option: C
Question 4: What is the main difference between opioid maintenance programs and traditional treatment programs? Options: A. Opioid maintenance programs are more expensive, B. Opioid maintenance programs require complete detoxification before beginning treatment, C. Opioid maintenance programs use medication to avoid withdrawal symptoms, D. Opioid maintenance programs are only available for people with severe addiction Correct Option: C
Question 5: What is the primary goal of opioid maintenance programs? Options: A. To completely eliminate opioid use, B. To reduce the risk of overdose, C. To address the physical and psychological aspects of addiction, D. To provide a temporary solution to opioid addiction Correct Option: C
Question 6: What is the name of the drug that is currently the best defense against opioid overdose? Options: A. Naloxone, B. Methadone, C. Buprenorphine, D. Fentanyl Correct Option: A
Question 7: Why are people who are addicted to opioids at high risk for overdose? Options: A. Because their tolerance has increased, B. Because they are taking too much of the drug, C. Because their body is too sensitive to noradrenaline, D. Because they are taking the drug too frequently Correct Option: A
Question 8: What is the main obstacle to accessing affordable treatment options for opioid addiction? Options: A. The lack of availability of treatment programs, B. The lack of access to medication, C. The high cost of treatment is too high, D. The waiting lists for treatment are too long Correct Option: C
Question 9: How do opioid maintenance programs address the physical and psychological aspects of addiction? Options: A. By providing complete detoxification before beginning treatment, B. By using medication to avoid withdrawal symptoms, C. By providing counseling and therapy, D. By providing a temporary solution to opioid addiction Correct Option: B
Question 10: What is the name of the helpline and database that can provide information and resources for people struggling with opioid addiction in the United States? Options: A. 800-662-4357 and www.hhs.gov/opioids, B. 800-662-4357 and www.samhsa.gov, C. 800-662-4357 and www.cdc.gov, D. 800-662-4357 and www.nida.nih.gov Correct Option: A


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is Question 3. 

However, it's worth noting that Question 3 doesn't perfectly match the ground truth MCQ, as it only addresses the effect of opioid binding on noradrenaline levels and not on dopamine levels. A more accurate match would be a question that addresses the effects of opioid binding on both dopamine and noradrenaline levels.

If we were to create a new question that combines elements of Questions 2 and 3, it would be a better match for the ground truth MCQ. However, based on the provided options, Question 3 is the closest match.

Here's why:

- Question 3 addresses the effect of opioid binding on noradrenaline levels, which is part of the ground truth MCQ.
- Question 3 has a similar structure and intent to the ground truth MCQ, as it asks about the primary cause of a specific effect (withdrawal symptoms) related to opioid binding.

Index of the most similar generated MCQ: 3

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 1, Question 2
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
More than 3,000 years ago, 
a flower began to appear in remedies in Ancient Egyptian medical texts. Across the Mediterranean, 
the ancient Minoans likely found ways to use 
the same plant for its high. Both ancient civilizations 
were on to something— opium, 
an extract of the poppy in question, can both induce pleasure 
and reduce pain. Though opium has remained 
in use ever since, it wasn’t until the 19th century 
that one of its chemical compounds, morphine, was identified 
and isolated for medical use. Morphine, codeine, and other substances 
made directly from the poppy are called opiates. In the 20th century, drug companies 
created a slew of synthetic substances similar to these opiates, including heroin, hydrocodone, 
oxycodone, and fentanyl. Whether synthetic or derived from opium, these compounds 
are collectively known as opioids. Synthetic or natural, legal or illicit, 
opioid drugs are very effective painkillers,
but they are also highly addictive. In the 1980s and 90s, pharmaceutical companies began 
to market opioid painkillers aggressively, actively downplaying 
their addictive potential to both the medical community 
and the public. The number of opioid painkillers 
prescriptions skyrocketed, and so did cases of opioid addiction, 
beginning a crisis that continues today. To understand why opioids 
are so addictive, it helps to trace how these drugs affect 
the human body from the first dose, through repeated use, 
to what happens when long-term use stops. Each of these drugs 
has slightly different chemistry, but all act on the body’s opioid system by
binding to opioid receptors in the brain. The body’s endorphins temper pain signals 
by binding to these receptors, and opioid drugs bind 
much more strongly, for longer. So opioid drugs can manage much more 
severe pain than endorphins can. Opioid receptors also influence everything
from mood to normal bodily functions. With these functions, too, 
opioids’ binding strength and durability mean their effects 
are more pronounced and widespread than those of the body’s 
natural signaling molecules. When a drug binds to opioid receptors, 
it triggers the release of dopamine, which is linked to feelings of pleasure 
and may be responsible for the sense of euphoria 
that characterizes an opioid high. At the same time, opioids suppress 
the release of noradrenaline, which influences wakefulness, breathing, 
digestion, and blood pressure. A therapeutic dose decreases noradrenaline
enough to cause side effects like constipation. At higher doses opioids can decrease heart
and breathing rates to dangerous levels, causing loss of consciousness 
and even death. Over time, the body starts 
to develop a tolerance for opioids. It may decrease its number 
of opioid receptors, or the receptors may become 
less responsive. To experience the same release of dopamine
and resulting mood effects as before, people have to take 
larger and larger doses— a cycle that leads to physical dependence 
and addiction. As people take more opioids 
to compensate for tolerance, noradrenaline levels 
become lower and lower, to a point that could impact 
basic bodily functions. The body compensates by increasing 
its number of noradrenaline receptors so it can detect much smaller amounts 
of noradrenaline. This increased sensitivity 
to noradrenaline allows the body 
to continue functioning normally— in fact, it becomes dependent on opioids 
to maintain the new balance. When someone who is physically dependent 
on opioids stops taking them abruptly, that balance is disrupted. Noradrenaline levels can increase 
within a day of ceasing opioid use. But the body takes much longer 
to get rid of all the extra noradrenaline receptors 
it made. That means there’s a period of time when the body is too sensitive 
to noradrenaline. This oversensitivity causes 
withdrawal symptoms, including muscle aches, stomach pains, 
fever, and vomiting. Though temporary, opioid withdrawal 
can be incredibly debilitating. In serious cases, someone in withdrawal 
can be violently ill for days or even weeks. People who are addicted to opioids 
aren't necessarily using the drugs to get high anymore, 
but rather to avoid being sick. Many risk losing wages or even jobs 
while in withdrawal, or may not have anyone to take care 
of them during withdrawal. If someone goes back 
to using opioids later, they can be at particularly high risk 
for overdose, because what would have been a standard 
dose while their tolerance was high, can now be lethal. Since 1980, accidental deaths 
from opioid overdose have grown exponentially 
in the United States, and opioid addictions have 
also exploded around the world. While opioid painkiller prescriptions 
are becoming more closely regulated, cases of overdose and addiction 
are still increasing, especially among younger people. Many of the early cases of addiction 
were middle-aged people who became addicted to painkillers 
they had been prescribed, or received from friends 
and family members with prescriptions. Today, young people are often introduced 
to prescription opioid drugs in those ways but move on to heroin or illicit 
synthetic opioids that are cheaper and easier to come by. Beyond tighter regulation 
of opioid painkillers, what can we do to reverse the growing 
rates of addiction and overdose? A drug called naloxone is currently 
our best defense against overdose. Naloxone binds to opioid receptors 
but doesn’t activate them. It blocks other opioids 
from binding to the receptors, and even knocks them off the receptors 
to reverse an overdose. Opioid addiction 
is rarely a stand-alone illness; frequently, people with opioid dependence 
are also struggling with a mental health condition. There are both inpatient 
and outpatient programs that combine medication, health services, 
and psychotherapy. But many of these programs 
are very expensive, and the more affordable options 
can have long waiting lists. They also often require complete 
detoxification from opioids before beginning treatment. Both the withdrawal period and the common 
months-long stay in a facility can be impossible for people who risk 
losing jobs and housing in that timeframe. Opioid maintenance programs aim 
to address some of these obstacles and eliminate opioid abuse 
using a combination of medication and behavior therapy. These programs avoid withdrawal symptoms 
with drugs that bind to opioid receptors 
but don’t have the psychoactive effects of painkillers, heroin, 
and other commonly abused opioids. Methadone and buprenorphine are the primary opioid maintenance 
drugs available today, but doctors need a special waiver 
to prescribe them— even though no specific training 
or certification is required to prescribe 
opioid painkillers. Buprenorphine can be so scarce that there’s even 
a growing black market for it. There’s still a long way to go 
with combating opioid addiction, but there are great resources 
for making sense of the treatment options. If you or someone you know is struggling 
with opioid use in the United States, the Department of Health 
and Human Services operates a helpline: 800-662-4357 and a database of more than 14,000 
substance abuse facilities in the US: www.hhs.gov/opioids

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Which of these compounds can be extracted directly from opium?
Options: A. Fentanyl, B. Morphine, C. Hydrocodone, D. Naloxone
Correct Option: B

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What was the first recorded use of opium in medical remedies? Options: A. Ancient Egyptian medical texts, B. Ancient Greek medical texts, C. Ancient Minoan medical texts, D. Ancient Chinese medical texts Correct Option: A
Question 2: How do opioid drugs primarily affect the body's opioid system? Options: A. By blocking opioid receptors, B. By increasing the production of endorphins, C. By decreasing the production of endorphins, D. By binding to opioid receptors Correct Option: D
Question 3: What is the primary cause of withdrawal symptoms in a person who is physically dependent on opioids? Options: A. The sudden decrease in dopamine levels, B. The sudden increase in dopamine levels, C. The sudden decrease in noradrenaline levels, D. The sudden increase in opioid receptors Correct Option: C
Question 4: What is the main difference between opioid maintenance programs and traditional treatment programs? Options: A. Opioid maintenance programs are more expensive, B. Opioid maintenance programs require complete detoxification before beginning treatment, C. Opioid maintenance programs use medication to avoid withdrawal symptoms, D. Opioid maintenance programs are only available for people with severe addiction Correct Option: C
Question 5: What is the primary goal of opioid maintenance programs? Options: A. To completely eliminate opioid use, B. To reduce the risk of overdose, C. To address the physical and psychological aspects of addiction, D. To provide a temporary solution to opioid addiction Correct Option: C
Question 6: What is the name of the drug that is currently the best defense against opioid overdose? Options: A. Naloxone, B. Methadone, C. Buprenorphine, D. Fentanyl Correct Option: A
Question 7: Why are people who are addicted to opioids at high risk for overdose? Options: A. Because their tolerance has increased, B. Because they are taking too much of the drug, C. Because their body is too sensitive to noradrenaline, D. Because they are taking the drug too frequently Correct Option: A
Question 8: What is the main obstacle to accessing affordable treatment options for opioid addiction? Options: A. The lack of availability of treatment programs, B. The lack of access to medication, C. The high cost of treatment is too high, D. The waiting lists for treatment are too long Correct Option: C
Question 9: How do opioid maintenance programs address the physical and psychological aspects of addiction? Options: A. By providing complete detoxification before beginning treatment, B. By using medication to avoid withdrawal symptoms, C. By providing counseling and therapy, D. By providing a temporary solution to opioid addiction Correct Option: B
Question 10: What is the name of the helpline and database that can provide information and resources for people struggling with opioid addiction in the United States? Options: A. 800-662-4357 and www.hhs.gov/opioids, B. 800-662-4357 and www.samhsa.gov, C. 800-662-4357 and www.cdc.gov, D. 800-662-4357 and www.nida.nih.gov Correct Option: A


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
After analyzing the ground truth MCQ and the generated MCQs, I found that the most similar generated MCQ is not an exact match, but Question 2 is the closest in terms of question intent and content.

However, since Question 2 does not directly address the specific compounds that can be extracted from opium, I re-examined the generated MCQs and found that none of them directly match the ground truth MCQ.

If I had to choose the most similar generated MCQ based on the topic of opium and opioid compounds, I would select Question 2, but with the understanding that it does not directly address the specific question of the ground truth MCQ.

Index of the most similar generated MCQ: 2

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 1, Question 3
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
More than 3,000 years ago, 
a flower began to appear in remedies in Ancient Egyptian medical texts. Across the Mediterranean, 
the ancient Minoans likely found ways to use 
the same plant for its high. Both ancient civilizations 
were on to something— opium, 
an extract of the poppy in question, can both induce pleasure 
and reduce pain. Though opium has remained 
in use ever since, it wasn’t until the 19th century 
that one of its chemical compounds, morphine, was identified 
and isolated for medical use. Morphine, codeine, and other substances 
made directly from the poppy are called opiates. In the 20th century, drug companies 
created a slew of synthetic substances similar to these opiates, including heroin, hydrocodone, 
oxycodone, and fentanyl. Whether synthetic or derived from opium, these compounds 
are collectively known as opioids. Synthetic or natural, legal or illicit, 
opioid drugs are very effective painkillers,
but they are also highly addictive. In the 1980s and 90s, pharmaceutical companies began 
to market opioid painkillers aggressively, actively downplaying 
their addictive potential to both the medical community 
and the public. The number of opioid painkillers 
prescriptions skyrocketed, and so did cases of opioid addiction, 
beginning a crisis that continues today. To understand why opioids 
are so addictive, it helps to trace how these drugs affect 
the human body from the first dose, through repeated use, 
to what happens when long-term use stops. Each of these drugs 
has slightly different chemistry, but all act on the body’s opioid system by
binding to opioid receptors in the brain. The body’s endorphins temper pain signals 
by binding to these receptors, and opioid drugs bind 
much more strongly, for longer. So opioid drugs can manage much more 
severe pain than endorphins can. Opioid receptors also influence everything
from mood to normal bodily functions. With these functions, too, 
opioids’ binding strength and durability mean their effects 
are more pronounced and widespread than those of the body’s 
natural signaling molecules. When a drug binds to opioid receptors, 
it triggers the release of dopamine, which is linked to feelings of pleasure 
and may be responsible for the sense of euphoria 
that characterizes an opioid high. At the same time, opioids suppress 
the release of noradrenaline, which influences wakefulness, breathing, 
digestion, and blood pressure. A therapeutic dose decreases noradrenaline
enough to cause side effects like constipation. At higher doses opioids can decrease heart
and breathing rates to dangerous levels, causing loss of consciousness 
and even death. Over time, the body starts 
to develop a tolerance for opioids. It may decrease its number 
of opioid receptors, or the receptors may become 
less responsive. To experience the same release of dopamine
and resulting mood effects as before, people have to take 
larger and larger doses— a cycle that leads to physical dependence 
and addiction. As people take more opioids 
to compensate for tolerance, noradrenaline levels 
become lower and lower, to a point that could impact 
basic bodily functions. The body compensates by increasing 
its number of noradrenaline receptors so it can detect much smaller amounts 
of noradrenaline. This increased sensitivity 
to noradrenaline allows the body 
to continue functioning normally— in fact, it becomes dependent on opioids 
to maintain the new balance. When someone who is physically dependent 
on opioids stops taking them abruptly, that balance is disrupted. Noradrenaline levels can increase 
within a day of ceasing opioid use. But the body takes much longer 
to get rid of all the extra noradrenaline receptors 
it made. That means there’s a period of time when the body is too sensitive 
to noradrenaline. This oversensitivity causes 
withdrawal symptoms, including muscle aches, stomach pains, 
fever, and vomiting. Though temporary, opioid withdrawal 
can be incredibly debilitating. In serious cases, someone in withdrawal 
can be violently ill for days or even weeks. People who are addicted to opioids 
aren't necessarily using the drugs to get high anymore, 
but rather to avoid being sick. Many risk losing wages or even jobs 
while in withdrawal, or may not have anyone to take care 
of them during withdrawal. If someone goes back 
to using opioids later, they can be at particularly high risk 
for overdose, because what would have been a standard 
dose while their tolerance was high, can now be lethal. Since 1980, accidental deaths 
from opioid overdose have grown exponentially 
in the United States, and opioid addictions have 
also exploded around the world. While opioid painkiller prescriptions 
are becoming more closely regulated, cases of overdose and addiction 
are still increasing, especially among younger people. Many of the early cases of addiction 
were middle-aged people who became addicted to painkillers 
they had been prescribed, or received from friends 
and family members with prescriptions. Today, young people are often introduced 
to prescription opioid drugs in those ways but move on to heroin or illicit 
synthetic opioids that are cheaper and easier to come by. Beyond tighter regulation 
of opioid painkillers, what can we do to reverse the growing 
rates of addiction and overdose? A drug called naloxone is currently 
our best defense against overdose. Naloxone binds to opioid receptors 
but doesn’t activate them. It blocks other opioids 
from binding to the receptors, and even knocks them off the receptors 
to reverse an overdose. Opioid addiction 
is rarely a stand-alone illness; frequently, people with opioid dependence 
are also struggling with a mental health condition. There are both inpatient 
and outpatient programs that combine medication, health services, 
and psychotherapy. But many of these programs 
are very expensive, and the more affordable options 
can have long waiting lists. They also often require complete 
detoxification from opioids before beginning treatment. Both the withdrawal period and the common 
months-long stay in a facility can be impossible for people who risk 
losing jobs and housing in that timeframe. Opioid maintenance programs aim 
to address some of these obstacles and eliminate opioid abuse 
using a combination of medication and behavior therapy. These programs avoid withdrawal symptoms 
with drugs that bind to opioid receptors 
but don’t have the psychoactive effects of painkillers, heroin, 
and other commonly abused opioids. Methadone and buprenorphine are the primary opioid maintenance 
drugs available today, but doctors need a special waiver 
to prescribe them— even though no specific training 
or certification is required to prescribe 
opioid painkillers. Buprenorphine can be so scarce that there’s even 
a growing black market for it. There’s still a long way to go 
with combating opioid addiction, but there are great resources 
for making sense of the treatment options. If you or someone you know is struggling 
with opioid use in the United States, the Department of Health 
and Human Services operates a helpline: 800-662-4357 and a database of more than 14,000 
substance abuse facilities in the US: www.hhs.gov/opioids

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: What effect does opioid binding have on other neurotransmitters?
Options: A. It inhibits the release of dopamine., B. It increases the release of noradrenaline., C. It inhibits the release of noradrenaline., D. It is easily displaced by endorphins.
Correct Option: C

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What was the first recorded use of opium in medical remedies? Options: A. Ancient Egyptian medical texts, B. Ancient Greek medical texts, C. Ancient Minoan medical texts, D. Ancient Chinese medical texts Correct Option: A

Question 3: What is the primary cause of withdrawal symptoms in a person who is physically dependent on opioids? Options: A. The sudden decrease in dopamine levels, B. The sudden increase in dopamine levels, C. The sudden decrease in noradrenaline levels, D. The sudden increase in opioid receptors Correct Option: C

By using medication to avoid withdrawal symptoms, C. By providing counseling and therapy, D. By providing a temporary solution to opioid addiction Correct Option: B
Question 10: What is the name of the helpline and database that can provide information and resources for people struggling with opioid addiction in the United States? Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is Question 3. 

This question is about the effect of opioid binding on other neurotransmitters, specifically noradrenaline, which is the same topic as the ground truth MCQ. The correct option in Question 3, "The sudden decrease in noradrenaline levels," is not exactly the same as the correct option in the ground truth MCQ, "It inhibits the release of noradrenaline." However, the two questions are addressing the same concept, and Question 3 is the closest match among the generated MCQs.

Index of the most similar generated MCQ: 3

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 1, Question 4
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
More than 3,000 years ago, 
a flower began to appear in remedies in Ancient Egyptian medical texts. Across the Mediterranean, 
the ancient Minoans likely found ways to use 
the same plant for its high. Both ancient civilizations 
were on to something— opium, 
an extract of the poppy in question, can both induce pleasure 
and reduce pain. Though opium has remained 
in use ever since, it wasn’t until the 19th century 
that one of its chemical compounds, morphine, was identified 
and isolated for medical use. Morphine, codeine, and other substances 
made directly from the poppy are called opiates. In the 20th century, drug companies 
created a slew of synthetic substances similar to these opiates, including heroin, hydrocodone, 
oxycodone, and fentanyl. Whether synthetic or derived from opium, these compounds 
are collectively known as opioids. Synthetic or natural, legal or illicit, 
opioid drugs are very effective painkillers,
but they are also highly addictive. In the 1980s and 90s, pharmaceutical companies began 
to market opioid painkillers aggressively, actively downplaying 
their addictive potential to both the medical community 
and the public. The number of opioid painkillers 
prescriptions skyrocketed, and so did cases of opioid addiction, 
beginning a crisis that continues today. To understand why opioids 
are so addictive, it helps to trace how these drugs affect 
the human body from the first dose, through repeated use, 
to what happens when long-term use stops. Each of these drugs 
has slightly different chemistry, but all act on the body’s opioid system by
binding to opioid receptors in the brain. The body’s endorphins temper pain signals 
by binding to these receptors, and opioid drugs bind 
much more strongly, for longer. So opioid drugs can manage much more 
severe pain than endorphins can. Opioid receptors also influence everything
from mood to normal bodily functions. With these functions, too, 
opioids’ binding strength and durability mean their effects 
are more pronounced and widespread than those of the body’s 
natural signaling molecules. When a drug binds to opioid receptors, 
it triggers the release of dopamine, which is linked to feelings of pleasure 
and may be responsible for the sense of euphoria 
that characterizes an opioid high. At the same time, opioids suppress 
the release of noradrenaline, which influences wakefulness, breathing, 
digestion, and blood pressure. A therapeutic dose decreases noradrenaline
enough to cause side effects like constipation. At higher doses opioids can decrease heart
and breathing rates to dangerous levels, causing loss of consciousness 
and even death. Over time, the body starts 
to develop a tolerance for opioids. It may decrease its number 
of opioid receptors, or the receptors may become 
less responsive. To experience the same release of dopamine
and resulting mood effects as before, people have to take 
larger and larger doses— a cycle that leads to physical dependence 
and addiction. As people take more opioids 
to compensate for tolerance, noradrenaline levels 
become lower and lower, to a point that could impact 
basic bodily functions. The body compensates by increasing 
its number of noradrenaline receptors so it can detect much smaller amounts 
of noradrenaline. This increased sensitivity 
to noradrenaline allows the body 
to continue functioning normally— in fact, it becomes dependent on opioids 
to maintain the new balance. When someone who is physically dependent 
on opioids stops taking them abruptly, that balance is disrupted. Noradrenaline levels can increase 
within a day of ceasing opioid use. But the body takes much longer 
to get rid of all the extra noradrenaline receptors 
it made. That means there’s a period of time when the body is too sensitive 
to noradrenaline. This oversensitivity causes 
withdrawal symptoms, including muscle aches, stomach pains, 
fever, and vomiting. Though temporary, opioid withdrawal 
can be incredibly debilitating. In serious cases, someone in withdrawal 
can be violently ill for days or even weeks. People who are addicted to opioids 
aren't necessarily using the drugs to get high anymore, 
but rather to avoid being sick. Many risk losing wages or even jobs 
while in withdrawal, or may not have anyone to take care 
of them during withdrawal. If someone goes back 
to using opioids later, they can be at particularly high risk 
for overdose, because what would have been a standard 
dose while their tolerance was high, can now be lethal. Since 1980, accidental deaths 
from opioid overdose have grown exponentially 
in the United States, and opioid addictions have 
also exploded around the world. While opioid painkiller prescriptions 
are becoming more closely regulated, cases of overdose and addiction 
are still increasing, especially among younger people. Many of the early cases of addiction 
were middle-aged people who became addicted to painkillers 
they had been prescribed, or received from friends 
and family members with prescriptions. Today, young people are often introduced 
to prescription opioid drugs in those ways but move on to heroin or illicit 
synthetic opioids that are cheaper and easier to come by. Beyond tighter regulation 
of opioid painkillers, what can we do to reverse the growing 
rates of addiction and overdose? A drug called naloxone is currently 
our best defense against overdose. Naloxone binds to opioid receptors 
but doesn’t activate them. It blocks other opioids 
from binding to the receptors, and even knocks them off the receptors 
to reverse an overdose. Opioid addiction 
is rarely a stand-alone illness; frequently, people with opioid dependence 
are also struggling with a mental health condition. There are both inpatient 
and outpatient programs that combine medication, health services, 
and psychotherapy. But many of these programs 
are very expensive, and the more affordable options 
can have long waiting lists. They also often require complete 
detoxification from opioids before beginning treatment. Both the withdrawal period and the common 
months-long stay in a facility can be impossible for people who risk 
losing jobs and housing in that timeframe. Opioid maintenance programs aim 
to address some of these obstacles and eliminate opioid abuse 
using a combination of medication and behavior therapy. These programs avoid withdrawal symptoms 
with drugs that bind to opioid receptors 
but don’t have the psychoactive effects of painkillers, heroin, 
and other commonly abused opioids. Methadone and buprenorphine are the primary opioid maintenance 
drugs available today, but doctors need a special waiver 
to prescribe them— even though no specific training 
or certification is required to prescribe 
opioid painkillers. Buprenorphine can be so scarce that there’s even 
a growing black market for it. There’s still a long way to go 
with combating opioid addiction, but there are great resources 
for making sense of the treatment options. If you or someone you know is struggling 
with opioid use in the United States, the Department of Health 
and Human Services operates a helpline: 800-662-4357 and a database of more than 14,000 
substance abuse facilities in the US: www.hhs.gov/opioids

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: What happens as the body develops a tolerance for opioids?
Options: A. Receptors become less responsive to opioids., B. Smaller doses of opioids are equally effective., C. The body increases its number of opioid receptors., D. Noradrenaline levels increase.
Correct Option: A

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What was the first recorded use of opium in medical remedies? Options: A. Ancient Egyptian medical texts, B. Ancient Greek medical texts, C. Ancient Minoan medical texts, D. Ancient Chinese medical texts Correct Option: A
Question 2: How do opioid drugs primarily affect the body's opioid system? Options: A. By blocking opioid receptors, B. By increasing the production of endorphins, C. By decreasing the production of endorphins, D. By binding to opioid receptors Correct Option: D
Question 3: What is the primary cause of withdrawal symptoms in a person who is physically dependent on opioids? Options: A. The sudden decrease in dopamine levels, B. The sudden increase in dopamine levels, C. The sudden decrease in noradrenaline levels, D. The sudden increase in opioid receptors Correct Option: C
Question 4: What is the main difference between opioid maintenance programs and traditional treatment programs? Options: A. Opioid maintenance programs are more expensive, B. Opioid maintenance programs require complete detoxification before beginning treatment, C. Opioid maintenance programs use medication to avoid withdrawal symptoms, D. Opioid maintenance programs are only available for people with severe addiction Correct Option: C
Question 5: What is the primary goal of opioid maintenance programs? Options: A. To completely eliminate opioid use, B. To reduce the risk of overdose, C. To address the physical and psychological aspects of addiction, D. To provide a temporary solution to opioid addiction Correct Option: C
Question 6: What is the name of the drug that is currently the best defense against opioid overdose? Options: A. Naloxone, B. Methadone, C. Buprenorphine, D. Fentanyl Correct Option: A
Question 7: Why are people who are addicted to opioids at high risk for overdose? Options: A. Because their tolerance has increased, B. Because they are taking too much of the drug, C. Because their body is too sensitive to noradrenaline, D. Because they are taking the drug too frequently Correct Option: A
Question 8: What is the main obstacle to accessing affordable treatment options for opioid addiction? Options: A. The lack of availability of treatment programs, B. The lack of access to medication, C. The high cost of treatment is too high, D. The waiting lists for treatment are too long Correct Option: C
Question 9: How do opioid maintenance programs address the physical and psychological aspects of addiction? Options: A. By providing complete detoxification before beginning treatment, B. By using medication to avoid withdrawal symptoms, C. By providing counseling and therapy, D. By providing a temporary solution to opioid addiction Correct Option: B
Question 10: What is the name of the helpline and database that can provide information and resources for people struggling with opioid addiction in the United States? Options: A. 800-662-4357 and www.hhs.gov/opioids, B. 800-662-4357 and www.samhsa.gov, C. 800-662-4357 and www.cdc.gov, D. 800-662-4357 and www.nida.nih.gov Correct Option: A


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is:

**Question 3: What is the primary cause of withdrawal symptoms in a person who is physically dependent on opioids?**

However, this question does not exactly match the ground truth MCQ. A more similar question would be one that directly addresses the concept of tolerance. Among the provided options, the closest match is:

**Question 2: How do opioid drugs primarily affect the body's opioid system?**

But this question still doesn't directly address tolerance. Since there isn't a question that directly matches the ground truth MCQ, I will choose the one that is closest in terms of content.

A more suitable match would be a question that mentions "receptors become less responsive" as an option, which is not present in the provided generated MCQs.

However, if I had to choose from the provided options, I would say that the closest match is:

**Question 3** is not the best match, but **Question 7** has some relation to tolerance.

The best match is not available, but if I had to choose: **7**

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 1, Question 5

**Transcript**:
More than 3,000 years ago, 
a flower began to appear in remedies in Ancient Egyptian medical texts. Across the Mediterranean, 
the ancient Minoans likely found ways to use 
the same plant for its high. Both ancient civilizations 
were on to something— opium, 
an extract of the poppy in question, can both induce pleasure 
and reduce pain. Though opium has remained 
in use ever since, it wasn’t until the 19th century 
that one of its chemical compounds, morphine, was identified 
and isolated for medical use. Morphine, codeine, and other substances 
made directly from the poppy are called opiates. In the 20th century, drug companies 
created a slew of synthetic substances similar to these opiates, including heroin, hydrocodone, 
oxycodone, and fentanyl. Whether synthetic or derived from opium, these compounds 
are collectively known as opioids. Synthetic or natural, legal or illicit, 
opioid drugs are very effective painkillers,
but they are also highly addictive. In the 1980s and 90s, pharmaceutical companies began 
to market opioid painkillers aggressively, actively downplaying 
their addictive potential to both the medical community 
and the public. The number of opioid painkillers 
prescriptions skyrocketed, and so did cases of opioid addiction, 
beginning a crisis that continues today. To understand why opioids 
are so addictive, it helps to trace how these drugs affect 
the human body from the first dose, through repeated use, 
to what happens when long-term use stops. Each of these drugs 
has slightly different chemistry, but all act on the body’s opioid system by
binding to opioid receptors in the brain. The body’s endorphins temper pain signals 
by binding to these receptors, and opioid drugs bind 
much more strongly, for longer. So opioid drugs can manage much more 
severe pain than endorphins can. Opioid receptors also influence everything
from mood to normal bodily functions. With these functions, too, 
opioids’ binding strength and durability mean their effects 
are more pronounced and widespread than those of the body’s 
natural signaling molecules. When a drug binds to opioid receptors, 
it triggers the release of dopamine, which is linked to feelings of pleasure 
and may be responsible for the sense of euphoria 
that characterizes an opioid high. At the same time, opioids suppress 
the release of noradrenaline, which influences wakefulness, breathing, 
digestion, and blood pressure. A therapeutic dose decreases noradrenaline
enough to cause side effects like constipation. At higher doses opioids can decrease heart
and breathing rates to dangerous levels, causing loss of consciousness 
and even death. Over time, the body starts 
to develop a tolerance for opioids. It may decrease its number 
of opioid receptors, or the receptors may become 
less responsive. To experience the same release of dopamine
and resulting mood effects as before, people have to take 
larger and larger doses— a cycle that leads to physical dependence 
and addiction. As people take more opioids 
to compensate for tolerance, noradrenaline levels 
become lower and lower, to a point that could impact 
basic bodily functions. The body compensates by increasing

to noradrenaline allows the body

to maintain the new balance. When someone who is physically dependent

within a day of ceasing opioid use. But the body takes much longer

it made. That means there’s a period of time when the body is too sensitive 
to noradrenaline. This oversensitivity causes 
withdrawal symptoms, including muscle aches, stomach pains, 
fever, and vomiting. Though temporary, opioid withdrawal 
can be incredibly debilitating. In serious cases, someone in withdrawal 
can be violently ill for days or even weeks. People who are addicted to opioids 
aren't necessarily using the drugs to get high anymore, 
but rather to avoid being sick. Many risk losing wages or even jobs 
while in withdrawal, or may not have anyone to take care 
of them during withdrawal. If someone goes back 
to using opioids later, they can be at particularly high risk 
for overdose, because what would have been a standard 
dose while their tolerance was high, can now be lethal. Since 1980, accidental deaths 
from opioid overdose have grown exponentially 
in the United States, and opioid addictions have 
also exploded around the world. While opioid painkiller prescriptions 
are becoming more closely regulated, cases of overdose and addiction 
are still increasing, especially among younger people. Many of the early cases of addiction 
were middle-aged people who became addicted to painkillers 
they had been prescribed, or received from friends 
and family members with prescriptions. Today, young people are often introduced 
to prescription opioid drugs in those ways but move on to heroin or illicit 
synthetic opioids that are cheaper and easier to come by. Beyond tighter regulation 
of opioid painkillers, what can we do to reverse the growing 
rates of addiction and overdose? A drug called naloxone is currently

from binding to the receptors, and even knocks them off the receptors 
to reverse an overdose. Opioid addiction 
is rarely a stand-alone illness; frequently, people with opioid dependence 
are also struggling with a mental health condition. There are both inpatient 
and outpatient programs that combine medication, health services, 
and psychotherapy. But many of these programs 
are very expensive, and the more affordable options 
can have long waiting lists. They also often require complete 
detoxification from opioids before beginning treatment. Both the withdrawal period and the common 
months-long stay in a facility can be impossible for people who risk 
losing jobs and housing in that timeframe. Opioid maintenance programs aim 
to address some of these obstacles and eliminate opioid abuse 
using a combination of medication and behavior therapy. These programs avoid withdrawal symptoms 
with drugs that bind to opioid receptors 
but don’t have the psychoactive effects of painkillers, heroin, 
and other commonly abused opioids. Methadone and buprenorphine are the primary opioid maintenance 
drugs available today, but doctors need a special waiver 
to prescribe them— even though no specific training 
or certification is required to prescribe 
opioid painkillers. Buprenorphine can be so scarce that there’s even 
a growing black market for it. There’s still a long way to go 
with combating opioid addiction, but there are great resources 
for making sense of the treatment options. If you or someone you know is struggling 
with opioid use in the United States, the Department of Health 
and Human Services operates a helpline: 800-662-4357 and a database of more than 14,000 
substance abuse facilities in the US: www.hhs.gov/opioids

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: What role does naloxone play in opioid addiction?
Options: A. It binds opioids to receptors more effectively., B. It is used in an overdose to provide pain relief., C. It stops addiction by binding to opioid receptors., D. It binds to opioid receptors without activating them.
Correct Option: D

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 1, Question 6
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
More than 3,000 years ago, 
a flower began to appear in remedies in Ancient Egyptian medical texts. Across the Mediterranean, 
the ancient Minoans likely found ways to use 
the same plant for its high. Both ancient civilizations 
were on to something— opium, 
an extract of the poppy in question, can both induce pleasure 
and reduce pain. Though opium has remained 
in use ever since, it wasn’t until the 19th century 
that one of its chemical compounds, morphine, was identified 
and isolated for medical use. Morphine, codeine, and other substances 
made directly from the poppy are called opiates. In the 20th century, drug companies 
created a slew of synthetic substances similar to these opiates, including heroin, hydrocodone, 
oxycodone, and fentanyl. Whether synthetic or derived from opium, these compounds 
are collectively known as opioids. Synthetic or natural, legal or illicit, 
opioid drugs are very effective painkillers,
but they are also highly addictive. In the 1980s and 90s, pharmaceutical companies began 
to market opioid painkillers aggressively, actively downplaying 
their addictive potential to both the medical community 
and the public. The number of opioid painkillers 
prescriptions skyrocketed, and so did cases of opioid addiction, 
beginning a crisis that continues today. To understand why opioids 
are so addictive, it helps to trace how these drugs affect 
the human body from the first dose, through repeated use, 
to what happens when long-term use stops. Each of these drugs 
has slightly different chemistry, but all act on the body’s opioid system by
binding to opioid receptors in the brain. The body’s endorphins temper pain signals 
by binding to these receptors, and opioid drugs bind 
much more strongly, for longer. So opioid drugs can manage much more 
severe pain than endorphins can. Opioid receptors also influence everything
from mood to normal bodily functions. With these functions, too, 
opioids’ binding strength and durability mean their effects 
are more pronounced and widespread than those of the body’s 
natural signaling molecules. When a drug binds to opioid receptors, 
it triggers the release of dopamine, which is linked to feelings of pleasure 
and may be responsible for the sense of euphoria 
that characterizes an opioid high. At the same time, opioids suppress 
the release of noradrenaline, which influences wakefulness, breathing, 
digestion, and blood pressure. A therapeutic dose decreases noradrenaline
enough to cause side effects like constipation. At higher doses opioids can decrease heart
and breathing rates to dangerous levels, causing loss of consciousness 
and even death. Over time, the body starts 
to develop a tolerance for opioids. It may decrease its number 
of opioid receptors, or the receptors may become 
less responsive. To experience the same release of dopamine
and resulting mood effects as before, people have to take 
larger and larger doses— a cycle that leads to physical dependence 
and addiction. As people take more opioids 
to compensate for tolerance, noradrenaline levels 
become lower and lower, to a point that could impact 
basic bodily functions. The body compensates by increasing 
its number of noradrenaline receptors so it can detect much smaller amounts 
of noradrenaline. This increased sensitivity 
to noradrenaline allows the body 
to continue functioning normally— in fact, it becomes dependent on opioids 
to maintain the new balance. When someone who is physically dependent 
on opioids stops taking them abruptly, that balance is disrupted. Noradrenaline levels can increase 
within a day of ceasing opioid use. But the body takes much longer 
to get rid of all the extra noradrenaline receptors 
it made. That means there’s a period of time when the body is too sensitive 
to noradrenaline. This oversensitivity causes 
withdrawal symptoms, including muscle aches, stomach pains, 
fever, and vomiting. Though temporary, opioid withdrawal 
can be incredibly debilitating. In serious cases, someone in withdrawal 
can be violently ill for days or even weeks. People who are addicted to opioids 
aren't necessarily using the drugs to get high anymore, 
but rather to avoid being sick. Many risk losing wages or even jobs 
while in withdrawal, or may not have anyone to take care 
of them during withdrawal. If someone goes back 
to using opioids later, they can be at particularly high risk 
for overdose, because what would have been a standard 
dose while their tolerance was high, can now be lethal. Since 1980, accidental deaths 
from opioid overdose have grown exponentially 
in the United States, and opioid addictions have 
also exploded around the world. While opioid painkiller prescriptions 
are becoming more closely regulated, cases of overdose and addiction 
are still increasing, especially among younger people. Many of the early cases of addiction 
were middle-aged people who became addicted to painkillers 
they had been prescribed, or received from friends 
and family members with prescriptions. Today, young people are often introduced 
to prescription opioid drugs in those ways but move on to heroin or illicit 
synthetic opioids that are cheaper and easier to come by. Beyond tighter regulation 
of opioid painkillers, what can we do to reverse the growing 
rates of addiction and overdose? A drug called naloxone is currently 
our best defense against overdose. Naloxone binds to opioid receptors 
but doesn’t activate them. It blocks other opioids 
from binding to the receptors, and even knocks them off the receptors 
to reverse an overdose. Opioid addiction 
is rarely a stand-alone illness; frequently, people with opioid dependence 
are also struggling with a mental health condition. There are both inpatient 
and outpatient programs that combine medication, health services, 
and psychotherapy. But many of these programs 
are very expensive, and the more affordable options 
can have long waiting lists. They also often require complete 
detoxification from opioids before beginning treatment. Both the withdrawal period and the common 
months-long stay in a facility can be impossible for people who risk 
losing jobs and housing in that timeframe. Opioid maintenance programs aim 
to address some of these obstacles and eliminate opioid abuse 
using a combination of medication and behavior therapy. These programs avoid withdrawal symptoms 
with drugs that bind to opioid receptors 
but don’t have the psychoactive effects of painkillers, heroin, 
and other commonly abused opioids. Methadone and buprenorphine are the primary opioid maintenance 
drugs available today, but doctors need a special waiver 
to prescribe them— even though no specific training 
or certification is required to prescribe 
opioid painkillers. Buprenorphine can be so scarce that there’s even 
a growing black market for it. There’s still a long way to go 
with combating opioid addiction, but there are great resources 
for making sense of the treatment options. If you or someone you know is struggling 
with opioid use in the United States, the Department of Health 
and Human Services operates a helpline: 800-662-4357 and a database of more than 14,000 
substance abuse facilities in the US: www.hhs.gov/opioids

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: How do opioid maintenance programs attempt to bring people back to a drug-free lifestyle?
Options: A. Replacement of opioids with other less addictive compounds like methadone., B. Behavioral therapy., C. Ongoing therapy to avoid relapse, D. Strict adherence to a daily medical regimen., E. All of these are part of an opioid maintenance program.
Correct Option: E

Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.

Question 6: What is a key characteristic of digraphs? Options: A. They are single letters that make one sound., B. They are combinations of two letters that make one sound., C. They are used to make new sounds when combined with other letters., D. They are only used in certain words. Correct Option: B
Question 7: Why are digraphs useful for readers? Options: A. They help readers to recognize words more quickly., B. They help readers to understand the meaning of words., C. They help readers to sound out words more accurately., D. They help readers to remember words more easily. Correct Option: C
Question 8: What sound do the letters "P" and "H" make together? Options: A. /sh/, B. /th/, C. /ph/, D. /wh/ Correct Option: C
Question 9: What is the relationship between digraphs and phonics? Options: A. Digraphs are a type of phonics., B. Phonics are a type of digraph., C. Digraphs and phonics are related concepts., D. Digraphs and phonics are unrelated concepts. Correct Option: C
Question 10: What sound do the letters "W" and "H" make together? Options: A. /sh/, B. /th/, C. /ph/, D. /wh/ Correct Option: D


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
After analyzing the ground truth MCQ and the generated MCQs, I found that the most similar generated MCQ is not an exact match, but Question 4 is the closest in terms of question intent and content.

However, a more suitable match can be found by analyzing the options in the generated MCQs. Question 10 has an option that includes "wh" which is the correct answer in the ground truth MCQ.

Therefore, the index of the most similar generated MCQ is: 8

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 5, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
[Music] hi I am a period I am used at the end of a complete [Music] thought I am a question mark right does anyone have any questions I am an exclamation mark I am used for strong feelings I am excited [Music] woohoo I am a comma I am used to make a pause between thoughts and also to list things I like cookies cupcakes and cucumbers yikes what is that I have no idea I like cookies cupcakes and cucumbers [Music] m

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Choose the punctuation mark for this sentence. My car is red
Options: A. ?, B. ., C. !
Correct Option: B

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is the primary function of a period in a sentence? Options: A. To list items, B. To make a pause between thoughts, C. To indicate the end of a complete thought, D. To express strong feelings Correct Option: C
Question 2: Which punctuation mark is used to make a pause between thoughts, including listing items, such as cookies, cupcakes, and cucumbers? Options: A. Exclamation mark, B. Comma, C. Period, D. Question mark Correct Option: B
Question 3: A writer uses an exclamation mark to convey strong feelings, such as excitement, as seen in "woohoo." Options: A. A question, B. A list of items, C. A complete thought, D. A strong feeling or excitement Correct Option: D
Question 4: What is the primary function of a comma in a sentence? Options: A. To separate clauses, B. To list items, C. To make a pause between thoughts, D. To indicate the end of a sentence Correct Option: C
Question 5: A writer lists items using which punctuation mark, such as cookies, cupcakes, and cucumbers? Options: A. Period, B. Comma, C. Exclamation mark, D. Question mark Correct Option: B
Question 6: A writer uses a question mark to express uncertainty or ask a question about a statement, as seen in "yikes, what is that?" Options: A. A personal opinion, B. A complete thought, C. A list of items, D. A statement they are unsure about Correct Option: D
Question 7: What is the relationship between a period and a complete thought in a sentence? Options: A. A period is used to separate clauses, B. A period is used to list items, C. A period is used to indicate the end of a complete thought, D. A period is used to express strong feelings Correct Option: C
Question 8: A writer uses an exclamation mark to express strong feelings or excitement, as seen in "woohoo." Options: A. A list of items, B. A complete thought, C. A personal opinion, D. A strong feeling or excitement Correct Option: D
Question 9: What is the primary function of a comma in a list of items, such as cookies, cupcakes, and cucumbers? Options: A. To separate clauses, B. To list items, C. To make a pause between thoughts, D. To indicate the end of a sentence Correct Option: B
Question 10: A writer uses a question mark to ask for clarification about a statement they are unsure about, as seen in "yikes, what is that?" Options: A. A personal opinion, B. A complete thought, C. A list of items, D. A statement they are unsure about Correct Option: D


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The ground truth MCQ is asking about the correct punctuation mark for a sentence ("My car is red"), which is a complete thought. The correct answer is a period (B). 

Among the generated MCQs, the ones that discuss the function of a period are Questions 1, 3 (incorrectly), and 7. 

- Question 1 asks about the primary function of a period, which is to indicate the end of a complete thought. 
- Question 7 asks about the relationship between a period and a complete thought in a sentence.

Between Questions 1 and 7, Question 1 is more focused on the function of a period, which aligns with the intent of the ground truth MCQ to choose the correct punctuation mark for a complete thought.

However, it's worth noting that the generated MCQs do not exactly match the format of the ground truth MCQ, as they do not provide a sentence and ask for the correct punctuation mark. Instead, they ask about the functions or relationships of punctuation marks in general.

Considering the available options, the most similar generated MCQ is Question 1.

Index of the most similar generated MCQ: 1

Question 1: What is the primary function of a period in a sentence? Options: A. To list items, B. To make a pause between thoughts, C. To indicate the end of a complete thought, D. To express strong feelings Correct Option: C
Question 2: Which punctuation mark is used to make a pause between thoughts, including listing items, such as cookies, cupcakes, and cucumbers? Options: A. Exclamation mark, B. Comma, C. Period, D. Question mark Correct Option: B
Question 3: A writer uses an exclamation mark to convey strong feelings, such as excitement, as seen in "woohoo." Options: A. A question, B. A list of items, C. A complete thought, D. A strong feeling or excitement Correct Option: D
Question 4: What is the primary function of a comma in a sentence? Options: A. To separate clauses, B. To list items, C. To make a pause between thoughts, D. To indicate the end of a sentence Correct Option: C
Question 5: A writer lists items using which punctuation mark, such as cookies, cupcakes, and cucumbers? Options: A. Period, B. Comma, C. Exclamation mark, D. Question mark Correct Option: B
Question 6: A writer uses a question mark to express uncertainty or ask a question about a statement, as seen in "yikes, what is that?" Options: A. A personal opinion, B. A complete thought, C. A list of items, D. A statement they are unsure about Correct Option: D
Question 7: What is the relationship between a period and a complete thought in a sentence? Options: A. A period is used to separate clauses, B. A period is used to list items, C. A period is used to indicate the end of a complete thought, D. A period is used to express strong feelings Correct Option: C
Question 8: A writer uses an exclamation mark to express strong feelings or excitement, as seen in "woohoo." Options: A. A list of items, B. A complete thought, C. A personal opinion, D. A strong feeling or excitement Correct Option: D
Question 9: What is the primary function of a comma in a list of items, such as cookies, cupcakes, and cucumbers? Options: A. To separate clauses, B. To list items, C. To make a pause between thoughts, D. To indicate the end of a sentence Correct Option: B
Question 10: A writer uses a question mark to ask for clarification about a statement they are unsure about, as seen in "yikes, what is that?" Options: A. A personal opinion, B. A complete thought, C. A list of items, D. A statement they are unsure about Correct Option: D


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The ground truth MCQ is asking about the correct punctuation mark for a sentence that is a question ("What is your name"). The correct answer is a question mark (?).

Among the generated MCQs, the ones that are most relevant to this topic are:

* Question 2: This question is about the function of a comma, but it also mentions other punctuation marks, including the question mark.
* Question 6: This question is about the use of a question mark to express uncertainty or ask a question.
* Question 10: This question is also about the use of a question mark to ask for clarification about a statement.

However, the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is not among the above options. The ground truth MCQ is asking about choosing the correct punctuation mark for a specific sentence, and none of the above questions have the same format.

But if we look at the options provided in the generated MCQs, we can see that Question 2 has options that include the question mark (D), and it is the only question that has the question mark as one of the options, along with other punctuation marks.

However, there isn't a generated MCQ that exactly matches the ground truth MCQ. But among the provided options, Question 6 is the closest match in terms of question intent, which is about the use of a question mark.

So, the index of the most similar generated MCQ is: 6

Matching Prompt:

**Transcript**:

**Ground Truth MCQ**:

Options: A. ., B. ?, C. ,
Correct Option: C

Question 4: What is the primary function of a comma in a sentence? Options: A. To separate clauses, B. To list items, C. To make a pause between thoughts, D. To indicate the end of a sentence Correct Option: C
Question 5: A writer lists items using which punctuation mark, such as cookies, cupcakes, and cucumbers? Options: A. Period, B. Comma, C. Exclamation mark, D. Question mark Correct Option: B
Question 6: A writer uses a question mark to express uncertainty or ask a question about a statement, as seen in "yikes, what is that?" Options: A. A personal opinion, B. A complete thought, C. A list of items, D. A statement they are unsure about Correct Option: D
Question 7: What is the relationship between a period and a complete thought in a sentence? Options: A. A period is used to separate clauses, B. A period is used to list items, C. A period is used to indicate the end of a complete thought, D. A period is used to express strong feelings Correct Option: C
Question 8: A writer uses an exclamation mark to express strong feelings or excitement, as seen in "woohoo." Options: A. A list of items, B. A complete thought, C. A personal opinion, D. A strong feeling or excitement Correct Option: D
Question 9: What is the primary function of a comma in a list of items, such as cookies, cupcakes, and cucumbers? Options: A. To separate clauses, B. To list items, C. To make a pause between thoughts, D. To indicate the end of a sentence Correct Option: B
Question 10: A writer uses a question mark to ask for clarification about a statement they are unsure about, as seen in "yikes, what is that?" Options: A. A personal opinion, B. A complete thought, C. A list of items, D. A statement they are unsure about Correct Option: D


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The ground truth MCQ is asking about the correct punctuation mark to use in a sentence that lists items. The correct answer is a comma.

Among the generated MCQs, the ones that are most similar in intent and content are:

* Question 2: Which punctuation mark is used to make a pause between thoughts, including listing items, such as cookies, cupcakes, and cucumbers?
* Question 5: A writer lists items using which punctuation mark, such as cookies, cupcakes, and cucumbers?
* Question 9: What is the primary function of a comma in a list of items, such as cookies, cupcakes, and cucumbers?

All three questions are asking about the correct punctuation mark to use when listing items, and the correct answer is a comma. However, Question 5 is the most similar in terms of intent and options, as it directly asks about the punctuation mark used to list items, and the options are straightforward.

Therefore, the index of the most similar generated MCQ is:

5

This question is the most similar to the ground truth MCQ in terms of intent, options, and content.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Fill in the blank with the correct sight word. You ____ me.
Options: A. so, B. to, C. is, D. and
Correct Option: A

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is the main topic of Dr. Taylor's discussion in the talk? Options: A. The benefits of technology in education, B. The importance of reading in modern society, C. The role of social media in shaping our perceptions, D. The impact of climate change on our daily lives Correct Option: B
Question 2: According to Dr. Taylor, what are some of the benefits of reading? Options: A. Improved physical strength and coordination, B. Enhanced cognitive skills, emotional intelligence, and social connections, C. Increased risk of eye strain and headaches, D. Decreased ability to focus and concentrate Correct Option: B
Question 3: Dr. Taylor mentions that reading can have a positive impact on our mental health. What specific benefits does she mention? Options: A. Reduced symptoms of anxiety and depression, lower blood pressure, and improved overall well-being, B. Increased risk of mental health issues, higher blood pressure, C. No impact on mental health, only physical benefits, D. Reduced stress and anxiety, but increased risk of depression Correct Option: A
Question 4: What does Dr. Taylor suggest we do to prioritize reading in our lives? Options: A. Reduce the time we spend reading and focus on other activities, B. Make reading a priority and encourage others to do the same, C. Read only for entertainment purposes and not for educational value, D. Avoid reading altogether and focus on other hobbies Correct Option: B
Question 5: According to Dr. Taylor, what can reading do for our perspectives and understanding of the world? Options: A. Narrow our perspectives and limit our understanding, B. Broaden our perspectives and foster a deeper understanding, C. Have no impact on our perspectives or understanding, D. Make us more ignorant and less empathetic Correct Option: B
Question 6: Dr. Taylor mentions that reading can be a source of relaxation and stress relief. What specific benefits does she mention? Options: A. Increased stress and anxiety, lower relaxation levels, B. Reduced symptoms of anxiety and depression, lower blood pressure, C. No impact on stress and relaxation levels, D. Increased risk of eye strain and headaches Correct Option: B
Question 7: What is one of the cognitive benefits of reading that Dr. Taylor mentions? Options: A. Improved physical strength and coordination, B. Enhanced vocabulary, concentration, and critical thinking skills, C. Increased risk of mental health issues, D. Decreased ability to focus and concentrate Correct Option: B
Question 8: According to Dr. Taylor, what can reading do for our emotional intelligence? Options: A. Decrease our emotional intelligence and empathy, B. Increase our emotional intelligence and empathy, C. Have no impact on our emotional intelligence, D. Make us more ignorant and less empathetic Correct Option: B
Question 9: What is one of the social benefits of reading that Dr. Taylor mentions? Options: A. Increased risk of social isolation and loneliness, B. Fostering social connections and a deeper understanding of others, C. No impact on social connections, D. Decreased ability to interact with others Correct Option: B
Question 10: According to Dr. Taylor, what should we do to make reading a priority in our lives? Options: A. Reduce the time we spend reading and focus on other activities, B. Make reading a priority and encourage others to do the same, C. Read only for entertainment purposes and not for educational value, D. Avoid reading altogether and focus on other hobbies Correct Option: B


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
None of the generated MCQs match the ground truth MCQ. The ground truth MCQ is focused on filling in the blank with the correct sight word, whereas the generated MCQs are focused on a discussion by Dr. Taylor, likely about the benefits of reading.

Since there is no match, I will not provide an index. However, if I had to choose the least dissimilar one, it would be a very weak match, and I would say that none of the generated MCQs have a similar intent or content to the ground truth MCQ.

If you'd like, I can try to help generate a new MCQ that would be more similar to the ground truth MCQ.
